column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0010] Many preliminary considerations are known regarding ways to control the coolant fluid in compressors against the background of the problems cited above.
#Text=A technical regulation principle in current use for controlling the temperature of a coolant fluid in compressors is disclosed, for example, in patent EP 0 067 949 B1.
#Text=Here a thermostatic slide valve determines whether coolant fluid is sent through a fluid cooler to be used for cooling, or is shunted past the cooler in order to raise the temperature.

#Text=With this form of regulation the temperature of the coolant fluid is kept relatively constant, and is set at a level such that on one hand it does not cause the temperature of the process fluid to fall below the condensation point, while on the other hand a temperature so high as potentially to damage the coolant fluid is avoided.
#Text=[0011] In patent U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 4,289,461 a further developed valve unit with an inlet and an outlet for coolant fluid is described.

#Text=Here again, the volume flow of the coolant fluid in a bypass conduit that bridges the fluid cooler is regulated, such that a portion of the flow of coolant fluid is always passed through the fluid cooler.

#Text=The regulation is achieved by means of a valve comprising two control units that act in opposite directions, one control unit operating dependent on the inlet temperature and the second one, dependent on the system temperature.

#Text=One of the disadvantages of this design is that the control valve is complicated in structure and subject to malfunction, and furthermore a certain minimal volume flow of coolant fluid passes through the fluid cooler.
#Text=Hence this proportion of the coolant fluid is constantly cooled, which thus also lowers the temperature of the process fluid.
#Text=[0012] Patent U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 4,431,390 discloses a form of regulation in which a second bypass conduit is also provided as a shunt around the fluid cooler.
#Text=In this second bypass conduit there is an additional valve which, when activated by a processor, allows a specific amount of coolant fluid to bypass the cooler in the form of a pulse.
#Text=The release of these pulses by the processor depends on various parameters.
#Text=Hence this solution is extremely elaborate to implement, both because multiple parameters must be monitored and evaluated and because an additional bypass conduit must be provided.

#Text=[0013] The solutions discussed above are predominantly concerned with the problem of keeping the coolant fluid in the compressor itself at a temperature such that water does not condense out and hence impairment of the coolant fluid and of the compressor is prevented.
#Text=At the same time, the forms of regulation here disclosed are designed so as also to avoid raising the coolant fluid to a temperature high enough to be potentially damaging.
#Text=However, the problems associated with the condensation of water while it is in the pneumatic consumer devices or in the conduits leading thereto are not addressed.
#Text=[0014] A variant of a solution relevant to this point is known from the patent DE 36 01 816 A1.
#Text=There the compressed process fluid, which has been heated to about 60.degree.
#Text=C. above the intake temperature of the compressor, is passed through an over dimensioned after cooler to bring it down to a temperature about 10.degree.
#Text=C. above the intake temperature.
#Text=A considerable proportion of the water vapor present in the process fluid is thereby caused to condense out and is eliminated by a condensate trap.

#Text=The compressed process fluid is subsequently sent to a heat exchanger where it is rewarmed so that ultimately--influenced to some degree by the current ambient parameters, which in this design are assumed to be unchanging--a process fluid is produced that is quite dry and about 60.degree.
#Text=C. above the intake temperature, i.e. very hot.
